title: 106_s1898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Interstate Transportation of Dangerous Criminals Act of 2000" or "Jeanna's Act." Congress finds that States are increasingly using private prisoner transport companies for violent prisoners, leading to escapes and the need for oversight by the Attorney General. Private prisoner transport companies have had escapes by violent prisoners during transport, leading to the need for oversight by the Attorney General. While most governmental entities prefer using trained law enforcement officers for transporting violent prisoners, fiscal or logistical concerns may prompt the use of specialized private transport companies. Governmental entities should not be required to contract with private companies for moving violent prisoners. Private prisoner transport companies may be used due to fiscal or logistical concerns, but should not be used for moving violent prisoners unless necessary. If a government entity chooses to use a private transport company for violent prisoners, regulations should be in place to ensure public safety. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "crime of violence" is defined as in section 924(c)(3) of title 18, United States Code. The term "private prisoner transport company" refers to any entity, other than the United States or a State, that transports individuals committed to the custody of a State for compensation. A "violent prisoner" is defined as an individual in the custody of a State. The term "violent prisoner" refers to individuals in the custody of a State or its subdivisions who have been convicted of a violent crime or are currently facing charges for such offenses. Federal regulation of prisoner transport companies. The Attorney General, in consultation with relevant organizations, will establish regulations for transporting violent prisoners across state lines, including background checks and drug testing for employees. Minimum standards for background checks and preemployment drug testing for potential employees, including criminal background checks to disqualify individuals with felony or domestic violence convictions. Preemployment drug testing must comply with State laws. Employees must undergo up to 100 hours of preservice training focused on prisoner transportation. State laws require employees to undergo up to 100 hours of preservice training for prisoner transportation, covering restraints, searches, use of force, CPR, map reading, and defensive driving. There are also restrictions on the number of hours employees can be on duty, following federal regulations on hours of service. Minimum standards for personnel supervising violent prisoners include a requirement of 1 agent for every 6 violent prisoners, along with standards for employee uniforms and identification. The procurement government entity must adhere to a requirement of 1 agent for every 6 violent prisoners. Employee uniforms must include a badge or insignia identifying them as transportation officers. Violent prisoners must wear brightly colored clothing for identification, and restraints like leg shackles and double-locked handcuffs must be used during transportation. (7) Prisoners must wear brightly colored clothing for identification. Minimum restraint requirements include leg shackles and double-locked handcuffs for violent prisoners during transportation. (8) Private transport companies must notify local law enforcement 24 hours before scheduled stops. (9) In case of a violent prisoner escape, transport company officials must immediately inform law enforcement. The regulations require private prisoner transport companies to notify local law enforcement 24 hours before scheduled stops and immediately inform them in case of a violent prisoner escape. Minimum safety standards for violent prisoners must be followed according to Federal and State law. Minimum safety standards for violent prisoners must be followed according to Federal and State law, with regulations not imposing stricter standards on private prisoner transport companies compared to the United States Marshals Service, Federal Bureau of Prisons, and Immigration and Naturalization Service. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. Violators of regulations under this Act may face a civil penalty up to $10,000 per violation, restitution to entities for costs related to apprehending escaped violent prisoners due to violations.
